Knowledge Point: Before examining \isi{coordination} between clauses, I consider how elements within \isi{phrase}s may be coordinated, starting with nouns within a \isi{noun phrase}. Nouns are coordinated within a \isi{noun phrase}s without any overt \isi{conjunction} or \isi{morphosyntactic} marking to indicate \isi{conjunction}. When the total \isi{number} of referents among the coordinated nouns in the NP equals two, then the entire NP may receive \isi{dual} subject marking or \isi{object marking}. When the total \isi{number} of referents is more than two, then the NP may receive \isi{plural} subject marking or \isi{object marking}. Examples \REF{ex:complex:1} through \REF{ex:complex:5} illustrate NPs in which two nouns are coordinated.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Dimes Susan min} luke i mapta minji itana mane. | \gll \textbf{Dimes} \textbf{Susan} \textbf{min} luke i ma=p-ta min-nji ita-na ma-n-e | \gls [name] [name] 3DU too go.PFV 3SG.OBJ=be{-cond} 3DU-POSS build-IRR go{-ipfv-dep} | \glt `If Dimes and Susan go there, too, [then they] are going to build their [house there].’
Content 2: \gsrc Nïtïne nïnji \textbf{wutï i} tembipe. | \gll nï=tï-n-e nï-nji \textbf{wutï} \textbf{i} tembi=p-e | \gls 1SG=take-PFV-DEP 1SG-POSS leg hand bad=COP{-dep} | \glt `When it got me, my legs and arms were injured.’

Knowledge Point: Although the \isi{noun phrase} in \REF{ex:complex:6} has exactly two referents, the \isi{plural} \isi{subject marker} ndï ‘\textsc{3pl}’ is used (\sectref{sec:9.1.2}).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Bill Elvis ndï} molop. | \gll \textbf{Bill} \textbf{Elvis} \textbf{ndï} ma=lo-p | \gls [name] [name] 3PL 3SG.OBJ=go-PFV | \glt `Bill and Elvis went there.’

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:complex:7} and \REF{ex:complex:8} provide examples of more than two nouns being coordinated within a single NP.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Awaka Mukamba Kawat ndï} mol i. | \gll \textbf{Awaka} \textbf{Mukamba} \textbf{Kawat} \textbf{ndï} ma=ul i | \gls [name] [name] [name] 3PL 3SG.OBJ=with go.PFV | \glt `Awaka, Mukamba, and Kawat came with him.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Anapa yawa ngata ndunduma ndï} wopa malanda. | \gll \textbf{anapa} \textbf{yawa} \textbf{ngata} \textbf{ndunduma} \textbf{ndï} wopa ma=la-nda | \gls sister uncle grand great-grandparent 3PL all 3SG.OBJ=eat-IRR | \glt `Sisters, uncles, grandparents, and great-grandparents would all eat it.’

Knowledge Point: \isi{Pronoun}s may also signal \isi{coordination}, namely, in \isi{inclusory construction}s, whereby a \isi{non-singular} referent is signaled by the \isi{juxtaposition} of one or more referents with either a \isi{dual} or \isi{plural} \isi{pronoun} immediately following it. In \REF{ex:complex:9}, the \isi{pronoun} an ‘1\textsc{pl.excl}’ signals the inclusion of the speaker in the set of ‘we’.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ganmali Dumngul an} molop lilïp. | \gll \textbf{Ganmali} \textbf{Dumngul} \textbf{an} ma=lo-p li-lï-p | \gls [name] [name] 1PL.EXCL 3SG.OBJ=cut-PFV down-put-PFV | \glt `Ganmali, Dumngul, and I cut it down.’

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:complex:10} and \REF{ex:complex:11} exemplify the use of \isi{dual inclusory pronoun}s.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Manama ngant}: … | \gll \textbf{Manama} \textbf{ngan}=ta | \gls [name] 1DU.EXCL=say | \glt `[He] told Manama and me: …’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Awandana nganwe} indape ngan iwa tï ndïnambïlïp indap. | \gll \textbf{Awandana} \textbf{ngan-we} inda-p-e ngan iwa tï ndï=nambï-lï-p inda-p | \gls [name] 1DU.EXCL-PART.INT walk-PFV-DEP 1DU.EXCL basket take 3PL=skin-put-PFV walk-PFV | \glt `When Awandana and I alone went, we two got the fish trap, blocked them, and went.’

Knowledge Point: \isi{Adjective}s may also be coordinated. In example \REF{ex:complex:12}, two \isi{adjective}s that are functioning as nouns are coordinated in the same NP.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Njukuta ambi} nen. | \gll \textbf{njukuta} \textbf{ambi} na-i-n | \gls small big DETR-come-PFV | \glt `Both big and small [people] came.’

Knowledge Point: \isi{Adjective}s may also be coordinated within a single \isi{noun phrase} \isi{head}ed by a single noun. Multiple \isi{adnominal adjective}s can be coordinated within subject NPs, as in \REF{ex:complex:13}, as well as within object NPs, as in \REF{ex:complex:14} and \REF{ex:complex:15}, or in isolated \isi{noun phrase}s, as in \REF{ex:complex:16}.
Content 1: \gsrc Tïn \textbf{mbunmana ambi} mï unip. | \gll tïn \textbf{mbunmana} \textbf{ambi} mï uni-p | \gls dog black big 3SG.SUBJ shout-PFV | \glt `The big, black dog barked.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï lïmndï wambana \textbf{ambi anma} mala. | \gll nï lïmndï wambana \textbf{ambi} \textbf{anma} ma=ala | \gls 1SG eye fish big good 3SG.OBJ=see | \glt `I saw a nice, big fish.’
Content 3: \gsrc Tïmbïl \textbf{ambi nïpat ngata} ndaytana. | \gll tïmbïl \textbf{ambi} \textbf{nïpat} \textbf{ngata} anda=ita-na | \gls fence big giant grant SG.DIST=build-IRR | \glt `[You] will build that big, huge, giant fence.’
Content 4: \gsrc Tokples \textbf{njukuta ilum} wa ndïtane. | \gll tokples \textbf{njukuta} \textbf{ilum} wa ndï=ta-n-e | \gls tokples small little just 3PL=say-IPFV-DEP | \glt `Little, short tokples [= vernacular] stories -- [I] am just telling them.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:complex:17} illustrates coordinated \isi{predicative adjective}s.
Content 1: \gsrc Namndu mï \textbf{ambi ngatape}. | \gll namndu mï \textbf{ambi} \textbf{ngata}=p-e | \gls pig 3SG.SUBJ big grand=COP{-dep} | \glt `The pig was really big.’

Knowledge Point: \isi{Verb phrase}s may also be coordinated. When multiple verbs are truly coordinated in the same \isi{verb phrase}, then the \isi{TAM} marking should match on all the verbs, as in \REF{ex:complex:18} and \REF{ex:complex:19}.
Content 1: \gsrc Alimban mï lamndu \textbf{masap mamap}. | \gll Alimban mï lamndu \textbf{ma=asa-p} \textbf{ma=ama-p} | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV 3SG.OBJ=eat-PFV | \glt `Alimban killed and ate the pig.’
Content 2: \gsrc Yawana mï utam \textbf{mawanap mamap}. | \gll Yawana mï utam \textbf{ma=wana-p} \textbf{ma=ama-p} | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ yam 3SG.OBJ=cook-PFV 3SG.OBJ=eat-PFV | \glt `Yawana cooked and ate the yam.’

Knowledge Point: The first verb may be unmarked, however, especially if it is an occasionally \isi{defective verb} (\sectref{sec:4.3}), as in \REF{ex:complex:20} and \REF{ex:complex:21}.
Content 1: \gsrc Min ko \textbf{mas mamap}. | \gll min ko \textbf{ma=asa} \textbf{ma=ama-p} | \gls 3DU just 3SG.OBJ=hit 3SG.OBJ=eat-PFV | \glt `The two killed and ate it.’
Content 2: \gsrc Guren mï lïmndï lamndu \textbf{mala masap}. | \gll Guren mï lïmndï lamndu \textbf{ma=ala} \textbf{ma=asa-p} | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ eye pig 3SG.OBJ=see 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV | \glt `Guren saw and killed the pig.’

Knowledge Point: Moreover, there should be no dependent marking \is{dependent marker}(\sectref{sec:12.2}) on anything other than the \isi{final verb} in the \isi{phrase}. Of course, given the \isi{homophony} of the \isi{imperfective} and \isi{dependent} forms (/-e/), it is sometimes difficult to determine whether a verb is receiving \isi{imperfective} marking (\sectref{sec:4.4}), dependent marking (\sectref{sec:12.2.1}), or both. In \REF{ex:complex:22}, I analyze wali- ‘hit’ as taking the \isi{imperfective} \isi{suffix} -e ‘\textsc{ipfv}’.
Content 1: \gsrc Lamndu \textbf{wale ndame}. | \gll lamndu \textbf{wali-e} \textbf{ndï=ama-e} | \gls pig hit-IPFV 3PL=eat-IPFV | \glt `[They] would kill and eat pigs.’

Knowledge Point: Although it is common for both verbs in a coordinated \isi{phrase} to receive \isi{object marking}, this is not mandatory: in example \REF{ex:complex:22}, only the second of the two coordinated verbs takes the \isi{object marker}.
Content 1: \gsrc Lamndu \textbf{wale ndame}. | \gll lamndu \textbf{wali-e} \textbf{ndï=ama-e} | \gls pig hit-IPFV 3PL=eat-IPFV | \glt `[They] would kill and eat pigs.’

Knowledge Point: If a sentence contains two verbs that have different objects, then it is assumed that the \isi{coordination} occurs not between two verbs within a single \isi{verb phrase} but rather between two \isi{verb phrase}s. However, it is not always clear whether there are two \isi{verb phrase}s being coordinated within a single clause or there are two clauses being coordinated within a larger sentence. This is because it is common in Ulwa to omit subjects (\sectref{sec:11.1}). Thus, although example \REF{ex:complex:23} is translated as though the \isi{coordination} occurs within a single clause, it could alternatively be the case that there are two full clauses being coordinated, but that the subject in the second clause is omitted (i.e., ‘Alimban killed the pig and [he] cooked the meat’).
Content 1: \gsrc Alimban mï \textbf{lamndu masap mundu nduwanap}. | \gll Alimban mï lamndu ma=\textbf{asa}-p mundu ndï=\textbf{wana}-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ pig 3SG.OBJ=hit-PFV food 3PL=cook-PFV | \glt `Alimban killed the pig and cooked the meat.’

Knowledge Point: This point leads to the focus of this section: the \isi{coordination} of clauses in Ulwa. When two clauses are presented on equal grammatical footing, there is no distinction made between the two. They are presented \isi{paratactic}ally, one after the other, without any \is{dependent marker} dependent marking -- that is, Ulwa employs \isi{asyndetic coordination}, as illustrated by sentences \REF{ex:complex:24}, \REF{ex:complex:25}, and \REF{ex:complex:26}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mangusuwa as mï nip. | \gll {[ma-ngusuwa} {asa]} {[mï} {ni-p]} | \gls {[3SG.OBJ-poor} {hit]} {[3SG.SUBJ} {die-PFV]} | \glt `[They] struck the poor thing and he died.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï mbïwap mokotïp. | \gll {[nï} {mbï-wap]} {[ma=kot-p]} | \gls {[1SG} here-be.PST] {[3SG.OBJ=break-PFV]} | \glt `I stayed here and [I] bore her.’
Content 3: \gsrc Mangusuwa mbïwap mï amun naman. | \gll {[ma-ngusuwa} {mbï-wap]} {[mï} amun {na-ma-n]} | \gls {[3SG.OBJ-poor} here-be.PST] {[3SG.SUBJ} now DETR-go-IPFV] | \glt `The poor thing stayed here and today she’s leaving.’

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:complex:24}, \REF{ex:complex:25}, and \REF{ex:complex:26} are all translated with ‘and’. Coordinated clauses can have \is{concessive coordination} \isi{concessive} (i.e., ‘but’) senses as well. Again, this is achieved without any overt \isi{coordinating conjunction} \REF{ex:complex:27}.
Content 1: \gsrc Mangusuwa as mï nip. | \gll {[ma-ngusuwa} {asa]} {[mï} {ni-p]} | \gls {[3SG.OBJ-poor} {hit]} {[3SG.SUBJ} {die-PFV]} | \glt `[They] struck the poor thing and he died.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nï mbïwap mokotïp. | \gll {[nï} {mbï-wap]} {[ma=kot-p]} | \gls {[1SG} here-be.PST] {[3SG.OBJ=break-PFV]} | \glt `I stayed here and [I] bore her.’
Content 3: \gsrc Mangusuwa mbïwap mï amun naman. | \gll {[ma-ngusuwa} {mbï-wap]} {[mï} amun {na-ma-n]} | \gls {[3SG.OBJ-poor} here-be.PST] {[3SG.SUBJ} now DETR-go-IPFV] | \glt `The poor thing stayed here and today she’s leaving.’
Content 4: \gsrc Mï ango maka Nïmalnu wa map mï nay. | \gll {[mï} ango maka Nïmalnu wa {ma=p]} {[mï} {na-i]} | \gls [3SG.SUBJ NEG thus Manu village 3SG.OBJ=be] [3SG.SUBJ DETR-go.PFV] | \glt `He didn’t stay in Manu village, but he went.’

Knowledge Point: It is common for speakers to \isi{borrow} words from \ili{Tok Pisin} when coordinated structures are desired, especially when they are \is{disjunctive coordination} disjunctive (i.e., ‘or’) structures, as in sentences \REF{ex:complex:28}, \REF{ex:complex:29}, and \REF{ex:complex:30}, which \isi{borrow} \ili{Tok Pisin} o ‘or’.
Content 1: \gsrc U wandam mana \textbf{o} nï wandam mana. | \gll u wandam ma-na \textbf{o} nï wandam ma-na | \gls 2SG jungle go-IRR or 2SG jungle go-IRR | \glt `Either you will go to the jungle or I will go to the jungle.’
Content 2: \gsrc Wambana tïn malanda \textbf{o} an ma wanwane angop i ndïwanap ndïlanda. | \gll wambana tï-n ma=la-nda \textbf{o} an ma wanwane ango-p i ndï=wana-p ndï=la-nda | \gls fish take-PFV 3SG.OBJ=eat-IRR or 1PL.EXCL go mushroom pull.out-PFV go.PFV 3PL=cook{-pfv} 3PL=eat{-irr} | \glt `Either [they] would catch a fish and [we] would eat it or we would go, pick mushrooms, go cook them, and eat them.’
Content 3: \gsrc Nï mana \textbf{o} nï mbïpïna nï ango kalam. | \gll nï ma-na \textbf{o} nï mbï-p-na nï ango kalam | \gls 1SG go-IRR or 1SG here-be-IRR 1SG NEG knowledge | \glt `Should I go or should I stay? I don’t know.’

Knowledge Point: This \ili{Tok Pisin} \isi{loanword} o ‘or’ is used not only to connect clauses, but also to connect elements within \isi{phrase}s, as in \REF{ex:complex:31}, \REF{ex:complex:32}, and \REF{ex:complex:33}.
Content 1: \gsrc Kawana mï mïnda \textbf{o} utam amap. | \gll Kawana mï mïnda \textbf{o} utam ama-p | \gls [name] 3SG.SUBJ banana or yam eat-PFV | \glt `Kawana ate either a banana or a yam.’
Content 2: \gsrc U \textbf{o} nï wandam mana. | \gll u \textbf{o} nï wandam ma-na | \gls 2SG or 1SG jungle go-IRR | \glt `Either you or I will go to the jungle.’
Content 3: \gsrc Mïnal \textbf{o} mil \textbf{o} utam \textbf{o} nongontam mï keka ndïn up. | \gll mïnal \textbf{o} mil \textbf{o} utam \textbf{o} nongontam mï keka ndï=n u-p | \gls taro or sugarcane or yam or kaukau 3SG.SUBJ completely 3PL=OBL put-PFV | \glt `[Whether it be] taro or sugarcane or yam or kaukau [= sweet potato], he planted them all.’

Knowledge Point: The \ili{Tok Pisin} \isi{loanword} na ‘and’ is also used in discourse to coordinate elements, whether words within a \isi{phrase} \REF{ex:complex:34}, \isi{phrase}s within a clause, or clauses within a sentence \REF{ex:complex:35}.
Content 1: \gsrc Bopten \textbf{na} Yar ngusuwa ndï wome mat ndïnane. | \gll Bopten \textbf{na} Yar ngusuwa ndï wome ma=tï ndï=na-n-e | \gls [place] and [place] poor 3PL middle 3PL=take 3PL=give-PFV-DEP | \glt `The poor [people from] Bopten and Yar gave them the middle [piece of land between Bopten and Yar villages].’
Content 2: \gsrc Tïklika \textbf{na} anmbi. | \gll tïkli-ka \textbf{na} an-mbï-i | \gls turn-let and out-here-go.PFV | \glt `[I] turned and came out.’

Knowledge Point: Some speakers use ma ‘and’ in certain coordinate structures. This seems more frequent among younger speakers and is perhaps a recent innovation. It bears a superficial resemblance to \ili{Tok Pisin} na ‘and’, but could instead be derived from the \isi{object marker} ma= ‘\textsc{3sg.obj}’ or the \isi{subject marker} mï ‘\textsc{3sg.subj}’.\footnote{This \isi{coordinator} is sometimes pronounced in a seemingly reduced way as [mï].} Regardless of its origins, as a connector within \isi{noun phrase}s, ma ‘and’ is limited in its usage, appearing almost exclusively after proper names, as in sentences \REF{ex:complex:36} through \REF{ex:complex:39}.
Content 1: \gsrc Nicko \textbf{ma} Danny min niya i. | \gll Nicko \textbf{ma} Danny min nï=iya i | \gls [name] and [name] 3DU 1SG=toward go.PFV | \glt `Nicko and Danny came to me.’
Content 2: \gsrc Nambul \textbf{ma} Wangasa min mawat pe ambinasap. | \gll Nambul \textbf{ma} Wangasa min ma=wat p-e ambin=asa-p | \gls [name] and [name] 3DU 3SG.OBJ=atop be{-dep} DU.REFL=hit-PFV | \glt `Nambul and Wangasa fought over it.’

Knowledge Point: The connector ma ‘and’ may be used to connect more than two \isi{proper noun} NPs, as in \REF{ex:complex:40}.
Content 1: \gsrc Lïmndï Ambayam \textbf{ma} Josephine \textbf{ma} Susan ndala. | \gll lïmndï Ambayam \textbf{ma} Josephine \textbf{ma} Susan ndï=ala | \gls eye [name] and [name] and [name] 3PL=see | \glt `[I] saw Ambayam, Josephine, and Susan.’

Knowledge Point: As a connector of NPs, ma ‘and’ may follow a \isi{proper noun} even when the other NP is a \isi{pronoun} \REF{ex:complex:41}.
Content 1: \gsrc Donna \textbf{ma} ndï molop. | \gll Donna \textbf{ma} ndï ma=lo-p | \gls [name] and 3PL 3SG.OBJ=go-PFV | \glt `Donna and they went there.’

Knowledge Point: As a clausal \isi{coordinator}, ma ‘and’ may even be derived from ma ‘go’, perhaps \isi{calque}d from \ili{Tok Pisin} uses of go ‘go’ as a discourse connector. Sentence \REF{ex:complex:42} suggests the ambiguity of the form [ma], which as a connector here could mean either ‘go’ or ‘and’.
Content 1: \gsrc Ay nïkap \textbf{ma} ndïmokota ndïnata mana. | \gll ay nïkï-p \textbf{ma} ndï=moko-ta ndï=na-ta ma-na | \gls sago dig-PFV and 3PL=take{-cond} 3PL=give-COND go-IRR | \glt `[I] have made sago and will go and give them [= servings of sago] to them.’

Knowledge Point: Sentences \REF{ex:complex:43} through \REF{ex:complex:48} contain \isi{dependent clause}s that bear causal relations to their respective \isi{independent clause}s.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Nïnji yanat mï tembipe} nonganup. | \gll \textbf{nï-nji} \textbf{yanat} \textbf{mï} \textbf{tembi=p-e} nongan-u-p | \gls 1SG-POSS daughter 3SG.SUBJ bad=COP{-dep} vomit-put-PFV | \glt `My daughter vomited because she was sick.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Wanmbi ulwape} nï wa aw ngan wa akïnaka landa man. | \gll \textbf{wanmbi} \textbf{ulwa=p-e} nï wa aw nga=n wa akïnaka la-nda ma-n | \gls daka nothing=COP-DEP 1SG just betel.nut SG.PROX=OBL just new eat-IRR go-IPFV | \glt `Since there’s no daka [= betel pepper], I’m just going to chew this betel nut fresh.’

Knowledge Point: Instead of the \isi{dependent marker} -e ‘\textsc{dep}’, the \isi{conditional} \isi{suffix} -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’ (\sectref{sec:4.12}, \sectref{sec:13.5}) may be affixed to the \isi{final verb} in a \isi{dependent clause}, providing a similar causal function as the \isi{dependent marker} -e ‘\textsc{dep}’ \REF{ex:complex:49}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Unanji ngata lanji luwa lawapta} maka apa ndaytana. | \gll unan-nji ngata ala-nji luwa ala=wap-\textbf{ta} maka apa anda=ita-na | \gls 1PL.INCL-POSS grand PL.DIST-POSS place PL.DIST=be.PST-COND thus house SG.DIST=build-IRR | \glt `Since those were our ancestors’

Knowledge Point: In sentences \REF{ex:complex:50} and \REF{ex:complex:51}, the \isi{dependent clause}s bear a \isi{concessive} relation to their associated \isi{independent clause}s.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Ndï ndïl kumat ine} kuma wa mïnwata wandam lïp. | \gll \textbf{ndï} \textbf{ndï=lï} \textbf{kuma=tï} \textbf{i-n-e} kuma wa mïnwata wandam lï-p | \gls 3PL 3PL=put some=take come-PFV-DEP some just rotting jungle put-PFV | \glt `Although they have brought some of them [home], [they] have left others just rotting in the jungle.’
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Wot mï maka lïmndï matïne} atuma mï nupu matïn. | \gll \textbf{wot} \textbf{mï} \textbf{maka} \textbf{lïmndï} \textbf{ma=tï-n-e} atuma mï nupu ma=tï-n | \gls younger 3SG.SUBJ thus eye 3SG.OBJ=take-PFV-DEP older.brother 3SG.SUBJ base 3SG.OBJ=take-PFV | \glt `Whereas the younger [brother] got the eye [side of the coconut], the older brother got the base [side of the coconut].’

Knowledge Point: Much like \isi{causal subordinate clause}s (\sectref{sec:12.2.2}), \isi{concessive} subordinate clauses may on occasion employ \isi{conditional} \isi{suffix}es in place of the \isi{dependent marker}, as in \REF{ex:complex:52}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Wa mïnomapïta ndin pïta} tem mat an mokolpe mï wa nambïtïn ninda! | \gll {wa} {mïnoma=p-\textbf{ta}} {ndï=in} {p-ta} {tem} {ma=tï} {an} {ma=kol-p-e} mï wa nambït=ïn ni-nda | \gls just cold=COP-COND 3PL=in be{-cond} time 3SG.OBJ=take out 3SG.OBJ=break-PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ just smell=OBL act-IRR | \glt `Even though [the meat] will get cold in them [= pots], when [you] have taken it out and broken it, it will just smell [good]!’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:complex:52} actually illustrates two \isi{dependent clause}s in succession: the first, a \isi{concessive} clause, is marked by the \isi{conditional} \isi{suffix} -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’; the second, a \isi{temporal} clause, is marked by the \isi{dependent marker} -e ‘\textsc{dep}’. This \isi{temporal} clause contains the \ili{Tok Pisin} \isi{loanword} taim ‘time’ (> Ulwa tem ‘time, when’), here functioning as a \isi{subordinator}. This \isi{loanword}, however, is not needed to form \isi{temporal subordinate clause}s, as shown in \sectref{sec:12.2.4}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Wa mïnomapïta ndin pïta} tem mat an mokolpe mï wa nambïtïn ninda! | \gll {wa} {mïnoma=p-\textbf{ta}} {ndï=in} {p-ta} {tem} {ma=tï} {an} {ma=kol-p-e} mï wa nambït=ïn ni-nda | \gls just cold=COP-COND 3PL=in be{-cond} time 3SG.OBJ=take out 3SG.OBJ=break-PFV-DEP 3SG.SUBJ just smell=OBL act-IRR | \glt `Even though [the meat] will get cold in them [= pots], when [you] have taken it out and broken it, it will just smell [good]!’

Knowledge Point: In sentence \REF{ex:complex:53}, the \isi{dependent marker} helps signal that the event referred to in the \isi{dependent clause} occurred \isi{simultaneous}ly to the action of the associated \isi{independent clause} (i.e., signaling the sense of ‘while’).
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Plas mambi ango mbïpe} nji tïngïn up. | \gll \textbf{Plas} \textbf{ma-ambi} \textbf{ango} \textbf{mbï-p-e} nji tïngïn=n u-p | \gls [name] 3SG.OBJ-TOP NEG here-be{-dep} thing many=OBL put-PFV | \glt `As for Plas, he didn’t plant many things while he was here.’

Knowledge Point: This \isi{temporal} sense is sometimes translated with ‘when’ in \ili{English} \REF{ex:complex:54}.
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{An njukutape} ndul inde. | \gll \textbf{an} \textbf{njukuta=p-e} ndï=ul inda-e | \gls 1PL.EXCL small=COP{-dep} 3PL=with walk-IPFV | \glt `When we were small, we went with them.’

Knowledge Point: As with other subordinate clause types, it is possible in \isi{temporal} constructions for the \isi{conditional} \isi{suffix} -ta ‘\textsc{cond}’ to occur at the end of the subordinate clause instead of the \isi{dependent marker} -e ‘\textsc{dep}’ \REF{ex:complex:55}.

Knowledge Point: Subordinate clauses marked with the \isi{dependent marker} -e ‘\textsc{dep}’ are used extensively in the rhetorical structure known as tail-head linkage, whereby the final clause of one sentence is more or less repeated at the start of the following sentence. In these structures, the \isi{final verb} of the first sentence is fully repeated somewhere in the first clause of the second sentence (i.e., it has the same exact \isi{object marker} and \isi{TAM} \isi{suffix}); the addition of the \isi{dependent marker} -e ‘\textsc{dep}’, however, allows the clause with the repeated verb to serve as a transition into a new \isi{independent clause}. In tail-head linkage constructions, it is possible for the entire pivot to be repeated exactly, as in \REF{ex:complex:65}.

Knowledge Point: It is also common for seemingly \isi{independent clause}s to receive the \isi{dependent marker} -e ‘\textsc{dep}’. In this way, when added almost as an afterthought, this \isi{suffix} can serve a sort of coordinating function, equivalent almost to a \isi{conjunction} ‘and’ in use. By affixing -e ‘\textsc{dep}’ to the end of a clause (and in so doing signaling that another clause is to follow), a speaker may have a better chance at holding the floor. Indeed, some speakers commonly insert the sound [-e] in the silence following a clause to signal that they are not yet done talking, as in examples \REF{ex:complex:72}, \REF{ex:complex:73}, and \REF{ex:complex:74}.

Knowledge Point: In Ulwa, there is no overt \isi{morphological} marker for relative clauses -- that is, there are no \isi{relative pronoun}s or \isi{relativizer}s, nor are there \isi{resumptive pronoun}s or other means of overtly coreferencing an argument in the \isi{relative clause} with an argument in the \isi{matrix clause}. A \isi{relative clause} immediately precedes the \isi{head noun} of the \isi{matrix clause}, and the verb in the \isi{relative clause} is marked for \isi{TAM} as any finite verb in a clause would be. Thus I analyze relative clauses as prenominal \isi{dependent clause}s with unexpressed subjects.\footnote{Relative clauses in Ulwa may thus be said to employ the \isi{gap strategy}, since the \isi{syntactic} spot where the \isi{head noun} of the \isi{antecedent} clause should be found in the \isi{relative clause} (i.e., before the verb) is empty (i.e., there is no overt \isi{phonological} form).} The basic structure of Ulwa relative clauses is outlined in \REF{ex:complex:80a}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: There are no \isi{correlative relative clause}s in Ulwa, nor are there \isi{adjoined relative clause}s (i.e., \isi{non-adjacent relative clause}s).\footnote{In an alternative analysis relative clauses in Ulwa may be considered \is{head-internal relative clause} head-internal, with the \isi{head} being expressed as a full NP only within the \isi{relative clause}, namely postverbally. A schematization of the head-internal analysis is given in \REF{ex:syntax:278} in \sectref{sec:13.7}. In this analysis, relative clauses would exhibit a different \isi{word order} from that found in most Ulwa clauses: whereas the \isi{word order} of \isi{pragmatic}ally neutral \is{active voice} active clauses is S(O)V (\sectref{sec:11.1}), the \isi{word order} of relative clauses would be (O)VS. While this analysis seems typologically unusual, it perhaps has some support when considered alongside Ulwa’s \isi{passive} constructions (\sectref{sec:13.7}). However, it does not seem best to analyze the \isi{head} as being internal, since it takes grammatical marking according to its role in the \isi{matrix clause}, not according to what its role would be within the \isi{embedded clause}. For example, we find the \isi{object marker} ma= ‘\textsc{3sg.obj}’ as opposed to the \isi{subject marker} mï ‘\textsc{3sg.subj}’ in sentences such as \REF{ex:complex:82}. Thus, it seems best to me to analyze relative clauses, like other subordinate clauses, as maintaining canonical S(O)V order and employing a \isi{gap strategy}.}

Knowledge Point: Relative clauses occur rarely in discourse, and some speakers (especially the younger ones) probably never employ them. Knowledge Point: There is yet another means of accomplishing the \isi{pragmatic} task of narrowing the reference of a noun. In addition to relative clauses (\sectref{sec:12.3}) and \isi{nominalized verb phrase}s (\sectref{sec:12.3.1}), speakers of Ulwa can make use of paratactic relative clauses (\citealt{ComrieKuteva2013}). In these constructions, there is no formal \isi{morphological} or \isi{syntactic} \isi{relativization}; rather, what could otherwise be expressed as \isi{matrix clause}s with \is{embedded clause} embedded relative clauses are here expressed by sets of two paratactically \isi{juxtaposed} clauses. Sentences \REF{ex:complex:100} through \REF{ex:complex:103} provide examples of paratactic relative clauses. The clauses in each example are enclosed in brackets.
Content 1: \gsrc Tembi la ndï wa mbïp. | \gll {[tembi} {ala]} {[ndï} wa {mbï-p]} | \gls {[bad} PL.DIST] [3PL village here-be] | \glt `Those people here in the village are bad.’
Content 2: \gsrc Numbu anma nda u mole. | \gll {[numbu} anma {anda]} {[u} {ma=lo-e]} | \gls [garamut good SG.DIST] [2SG 3SG.OBJ=cut-IPFV] | \glt `That’s a good garamut drum that you’re carving.’

Knowledge Point: Whereas \isi{dependent-marked} clauses do not participate in prototypical clause-chaining structures, there is one verb, tï- ‘take’, which does appear to behave as a \isi{medial verb}, albeit in a very restricted way. It may occur as the first of two verbs within a series of two clauses, taking its own object argument, but lacking \isi{TAM} marking, as in \REF{ex:complex:104}.
Content 1: \gsrc Un ango ame \textbf{tï inde}. | \gll un ango ame \textbf{tï} \textbf{inda-e} | \gls 2PL NEG basket take walk-IPFV | \glt `You don’t carry baskets around.’

Knowledge Point: It is rare for tï- ‘take’ to occur with other \isi{medial verb}s (if it itself may be considered to be a \isi{medial verb}); rather, such “clause chains” formed with tï- ‘take’ are generally restricted to this verb plus one verb in an immediately following final clause.\footnote{Often, tï- ‘take’ is \isi{phonological}ly reduced to [t] in such constructions. The verb is perhaps in the diachronic process of \isi{grammaticalizing} to become a \isi{postposition}.} The most common \isi{medial-clause} use of tï- ‘take’ is found in ‘giving’ constructions, which typically use na- ‘give’ as the verb in the final clause (see \sectref{sec:11.3} for examples as well as further discussion on other possible “\isi{ditransitive}” constructions in the language). It may also be used with a \isi{motion} verb (typically inda- ‘walk’) as the \isi{final verb}, giving the meaning ‘carry’, as in \REF{ex:complex:104}, and further illustrated by \REF{ex:complex:105} and \REF{ex:complex:106}.
Content 1: \gsrc Un ango ame \textbf{tï inde}. | \gll un ango ame \textbf{tï} \textbf{inda-e} | \gls 2PL NEG basket take walk-IPFV | \glt `You don’t carry baskets around.’

Knowledge Point: If the \isi{goal} argument (the \isi{location} to which something is brought) is encoded, then it is typically done so as the argument of a subsequent clause -- that is, not within a chained clause, but rather within another final clause following the chained group of \isi{medial clause} and final clause, as in \REF{ex:complex:110}.
Content 1: \gsrc Ndït i \textbf{Wopata may}. | \gll ndï=tï i \textbf{Wopata} \textbf{ma=i} | \gls 3PL=take go.PFV [place] 3SG.OBJ=go.PFV | \glt `I brought them [= fish] to Wopata.’

Knowledge Point: When the \isi{goal} is functioning rather more \isi{adverb}ially, as in \REF{ex:complex:109} (i.e., li ‘down’) or in \REF{ex:complex:111} (i.e., wa ‘village’), then it may be included once within a \isi{clause chain} consisting of a \isi{medial clause} and a final clause.
